j.algo

Class UnionFind

  • java.lang.Object
    • j.algo.UnionFind
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class UnionFind
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    An implementation of the union find solution with ranking and path compression. The elements are modeled as a forest with elements in each tree being in the same set. Each tree has a canonical root. This class is not thread-safe.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      Constructor and Description
      UnionFind(int numElems)
      Constructs an instance with a specified number of elements.

      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean areAllConnected()

      Checks whether two elements are in the same set.

    • Constructor Detail

      • UnionFind

        public UnionFind(int numElems)
        Constructs an instance with a specified number of elements. All elements are initially disjoint, that is, each element exists in a unique set by itself.
        Parameters:
        numElems - The total number of elements.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if numElems is non-positive.

    • Method Detail

      • connected

        public boolean connected(int a,
                int b)
        Checks whether two elements are in the same set. The order of specifying the element indices does not matter.
        Parameters:
        a - The zero-based index of the first element.
        b - The zero-based index of the other element.
        Returns:
        true if a and b are in the same set or a and b are the same; false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if a or b is negative or out of bounds.

      • union

        public boolean union(int a,
            int b)
        Union the sets that contain two specified elements. The order of specifying the elements does not matter.
        Parameters:
        a - Zero-based index of the first element.
        b - Zero-based index of the other element.
        Returns:
        true if the two sets are disjoint prior to union; false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if a or b is negative or out of bounds.

      • getDistinctCount

        public int getDistinctCount()
        Gets the number of disjoint sets.
        Returns:
        Returns a number between 1 and the total number of elements, inclusively.

      • areAllConnected

        public boolean areAllConnected()
        Checks whether all the elements are connected together, that is, they are all in the same set.
